summary.content: This book is not for reading—it is for striking. It is a hammer: not to destroy merely, but to test the hollowness of modern idols. If they ring false, they deserve to be shattered. Morality, reason, metaphysics, Christianity—these are the enemies of life. Let no one approach without fire in the belly and laughter on the lips. For only he who laughs has truly understood.

Wisdom does not shout—it whispers in daggers. Aphorisms are the tools of the free spirit. Here: What does not kill me makes me stronger. Idleness is the beginning of all psychology. Convictions are prisons. One repays a teacher poorly if one remains a pupil. Every truth begins as a blasphemy. Let these arrows fly into the soul of modern man—and wound his comfort.

Socrates—symptom of degeneration. He made reason tyrant. He was ugly, inside and out, and ugliness breeds resentment. His dialectic was a weapon of the weak—a way to trap life in syllogisms. He reversed instincts, made knowledge a virtue, and thus prepared the ground for Christianity. That he needed to die was not injustice, but justice: his death was a cleansing.

Philosophy has despised the senses for too long. It dreamed of the ‘real world’ behind appearances—and in doing so, murdered reality. Concepts are the corpses of intuition. 'Being,' 'thing-in-itself,' 'cause'—these are errors fossilized by language. Plato and Kant are theologians in disguise. Truth? It is a mobile army of metaphors. The senses do not lie—philosophers do.

summary.section: How the 'True World' Finally Became a Fable
summary.content: The history of philosophy is the history of a great error: belief in a 'true world' beyond appearances. Plato dreamed it, Christianity sanctified it, Kant obscured it, and we moderns have killed it. What remains? The world—as it is, with no beyond, no purpose, no morality baked in. We must learn to love this world. The 'real world'—we have abolished it. What world remains? The apparent one—joyously so!

All great moral systems have sought to tame man by castrating him. They wage war on the instincts—on sexuality, pride, revenge, joy. But instincts are not evil—they are life. Morality, especially Christian morality, is anti-natural: it teaches man to despise his drives. Virtue must be redefined: not as obedience, but as the sublimation and affirmation of instincts. Self-mastery, not self-denial.

Error one: confusing cause and effect. Morality claims virtue leads to happiness—but it is health and strength that cause virtue. Error two: false causality. We invent agents and gods to explain what we don’t understand. Error three: imaginary causes. Free will, intentions, soul—all illusions. Error four: misreading consequences as proof of intentions. Morality thrives on these errors. To destroy them is to liberate life.

The so-called improvers—priests, philosophers, moralists—have not elevated man; they have broken him. They have tortured instincts, tamed passions, bred guilt. Their 'improvements' were castrations. Asceticism, piety, repentance—these are not strengths but symptoms of decline. Greatness lies not in obedience but in overflow. Life is not to be purified but intensified.

The Germans—so rich in music, so poor in taste. They lack style, subtlety, and philosophical courage. They confuse depth with heaviness, and their seriousness is plodding. German philosophy has become a swamp—muddied by the bombast of Kant, Hegel, and their ilk. Even Wagner, once a hero, succumbs to Christianity in notes. Where is the light-footed philosopher? Where is Dionysus?

I am not of this age. I attack its values, its smugness, its sickness. Against democracy—I raise the flag of rank. Against pity—I raise the hammer of strength. Against equality—I proclaim hierarchy. Against morality—I offer style. Let man be overcome—not through sermons, but through dance, through laughter, through danger. The future belongs to the daring, not the dutiful.

summary.section: What I Owe to the Ancients
summary.content: To the Greeks I owe clarity, courage, and affirmation. But not to Plato—who betrayed them by turning toward heaven. I honor the pre-Socratics, the tragedians, those who embraced chaos with song. The Greeks said Yes to life, even in suffering. Tragedy was their answer to pessimism: not retreat, but transfiguration. Let us not return to antiquity, but return to their spirit: the spirit of Dionysus.

We are at the twilight of all idols—idols of God, of morality, of truth, of man. They were lies, comforts, excuses. They dulled life instead of sharpening it. I write not to persuade, but to provoke. Philosophy must no longer be scholasticism—it must be war. War against illusions, against decency, against nihilism in disguise. With my hammer, I prepare the dawn. Smash the idols—so that something stronger may rise in their dust.
